Author: danielha
Content:
Here's a blog post by Aaron Swartz: http://www.aaronsw.com/weblog/rlrr

In there, he proposes that "release early, release often" works in open source, but is less applicable to a wide public who are not expecting something unpolished and incomplete. When you only get one chance to make an impression, the unveiling might need a lot more consideration. Of course, then your product might never even see the light of day because it's been tied up for so long.

This is a different view from that in PG's essay, and it just shows the added complexity in decision-making a startup must go through.

Author: brett
Content: The earlier you set up your own servers and take care of them the better you'll be at it. If your seriously strapped for time maybe you can put it off, but it's a skill you want to have.

Author: danielha
Title: TellMe Networks may fetch more than $800 million in acquisition by Microsoft

Author: danielha
Content:
I would not run unnecessary risks just to avoid being "average". Would you?

Sometimes being a rebel-without-a-cause isn't the best approach.

Author: imp
Content: Microsoft expanded quite a few markets before it shrunk the encyclopedia market.

Author: danielha
Title: Michael Arrington/Timothy Bray debate on Web 2.0 -- 3/19, Sun in Menlo Park (free admission)

Author: danielha
Content:
YC-organized Startup School supplies advice to a larger audience, along with a chance for connections. I'd also contend that news.yc is another such tool offered by YC.

The summer/winter batches are a chance for picked companies to receive specialized attention. YC can't do that for everybody.
